title: The $6,000 Save — Cursor Usage Tracker Demo
description: 90-second product demo showing how automated anomaly detection catches costly usage patterns and saves money via Slack alerts.

candidates.name: Adam
candidates.style: Deep, neutral American, most popular narration voice
candidates.note: Industry standard for tutorials. May be recognizable.

candidates.name: Brian
candidates.note: Less overused than Adam, feels more natural.

candidates.name: George
candidates.note: Stands out, gives authority without sounding corporate.

scenes.label: Hook — The question
scenes.narration: Your team is spending twenty-five thousand dollars a month on Cursor. Do you know where it's going?
scenes.screen: Dashboard home page. Stat cards visible: 65 members, ~$25k team spend. Daily spend chart in background.
scenes.tips: Start with dashboard already loaded. Let the numbers speak — don't move the mouse yet.

scenes.label: Problem — The invisible cost spike
scenes.narration: Meet Elena. She didn't start new conversations for a week. Her context window grew to fifteen million tokens, and her cost per request went from seventy-two cents to over six dollars.
scenes.screen: Click on Elena Berg in the members table. Her user page loads showing the spend chart with the $/req line spiking on Feb 10-11. Hover over the spike to show the tooltip with $/req value.
scenes.tips: Click Elena right as 'Meet Elena' is spoken. The purple $/req line spiking is the visual proof — hover over it to show the tooltip.

scenes.label: Solution — Automatic detection
scenes.narration: Cursor Usage Tracker caught it automatically — running anomaly detection across your entire team. Static thresholds, z-scores, and trend analysis.
scenes.screen: Navigate to the Anomalies page. Elena's critical alert is visible: 'cycle spend $3,513 is 40.1x the team median'. Show the incident timeline with MTTD/MTTI/MTTR cards.
scenes.tips: Hover over Elena's anomaly row briefly so the detail is readable. The MTTD cards at the top sell the operational maturity.

scenes.label: USP — Slack notification
scenes.narration: And the moment it happened, you got a Slack alert.
scenes.screen: Show the Slack message in a channel. The alert block shows: user name, severity, dollar amount, model used. Linger on this for 3-4 seconds.
scenes.tips: THIS IS THE HERO SHOT. Zoom in slightly if editing. The Slack message is what makes this different from just a dashboard.

scenes.label: Proof — The before/after
scenes.narration: One message. You tell the team to start fresh conversations. Costs drop eight-x overnight. Six thousand dollars saved.
scenes.screen: Back to Elena's user page. Point out or highlight the spend chart showing the drop after Feb 14. The before/after is dramatic.
scenes.tips: The visual contrast in the spend chart is the wow moment — the drop after Feb 14 is dramatic.

scenes.label: Montage — Other catches
scenes.narration: It also catches expensive model switches, plan exhaustion on day one, and unused seats burning three hundred sixty dollars a month.
scenes.screen: Quick cuts: (1) Marcus's anomaly showing $14.55/req model switch, 2 sec. (2) Nina's plan exhaustion alert, 2 sec. (3) Members table sorted by activity showing zeros at bottom, 2 sec.
scenes.tips: These are fast cuts — 2 seconds each. Pre-navigate to each view in separate browser tabs so you can switch quickly.

scenes.label: CTA — Open source, deploy now
scenes.narration: Open source. Self-hosted. Deploy with Docker in five minutes. Start saving before the next billing cycle.
scenes.screen: GitHub repo page showing the README. Docker compose section visible. Star count visible.
scenes.tips: End on the GitHub page. If you want, click the Star button as a subtle call-to-action.

notes: Run mock data first: npm run generate:mock && DATABASE_PATH=data/mock.db npm run dev -- -p 3456
Pre-open all pages in browser tabs before recording: home, Elena's page, anomalies, Slack, Marcus anomaly, Nina anomaly, members sorted, GitHub repo
Record each scene as a separate screen recording clip
The Slack screenshot can be a real screenshot or a mock — either works
For the montage scene, consider recording 3 separate clips and cutting between them
